issue.title: Clear _modificationCommandGraph when returning the context to pool

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Reset StateManager and DatabaseFacade more consistently.
Fix functional tests so they actually return the context to the pool.

Fixes #32652

body: Will this make it into a EF Core 8 patch? If not, is the call to ctx.ChangeTracker.Clear(); enough to mitigate this issue?

issue.title: DbContext from pool contains many InternalEntityEntry instances after clearing change tracker

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

body: @MoMack20 no, unfortunately, calling `context.ChangeTracker.Clear();` is not enough to mitigate the issue as you can see in [my other issue](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/33354)
@mu88 Looking at the milestone, it should be fixed in version 9.0. I have given up using PooledDbContext, and the non-pooled performance is also very good.

issue.title: Sudden spike of DbContext although pooling is enabled

repository.name: efcore.pg
repository.description: Entity Framework Core provider for PostgreSQL

issue.body:
Hi 

Since https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/32652 has been resolved with .NET 9, I enabled `DbContext` pooling in our app again. Now the memory footprint is fine (i.e. my original issue has been resolved).

However, I'm now seeing sudden spikes in the number of `DbContext`s although they're supposed to be pooled:  
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8617c4a9-7c5a-4143-be23-62b6dec8c3d9)

We're talking about thousands of `DbContext` instances within a short time:  
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1acd42f1-be24-4846-85a1-38e6432023ad)

Neither from the app nor DB perspective do I see anything suspicious.

Do you guys know what is the reason for those spikes?

Thx!
